so when setting up a shot like this one
of the things you need to do is get a
good track I'm using cynthaiz here to
get a good track you need to mask off
anything that's going to cause problems
for the solver so things like things
have a mirror finish like the TV there
in the background or things that move
that might confuse the camera and make
it think that there's something actually
going on with the camera versus it's a
thing moving so Bruno's arm was moving I
needed to mask that off you also want to
make sure you have a lot of points in
your final track so that when you bring
it in your 3d application you can
actually recognize these objects and
know where things are makes it a lot
easier you can put objects into the
scene and export those but it's nice to
have all these nulls in there because
then you can parent right to a specific
spot in the scene so once you've got a
good solve like this and I can see the
table I can see those flowers on the
wall above the TV I can see where
everything is
you're gonna export it to your 3d
application once I've got everything
imported into Softimage I need to set up
the camera from cynthaiz it came in as a
d1 camera with the wrong aspect ratio
you got to make sure you check that also
you're going to need a background plate
of your images from the track so here
I'm setting up a background plate so
that when any object that's transparent
is going in front of the camera you can
pick up the background image through the
transparent object from there what you
want to do is start bringing in objects
that you've already modeled previously
here I'm going to go load a glass with
some liquid spilling out of it and since
I have all those nulls I know it's going
to be right on the table I can see
exactly where the table is so bring in
the glass I'm gonna go ahead and put
that where it belongs then I need to set
up the lighting for the shot to match
normally you'd like to try to get a
light probe of the location where you've
shot but if you don't have that one of
the great things you can use is si BL
or from HDR labs it is a free program
that has lots of great light probes from
all over the world and what I do did for
this is I went and looked for one that
matches sort of the location of where we
were
I needed something with some Reds some
muted lighting but outdoor coming
through windows so I picked wano shrine
which had similar colors to the scene
that I was working on next thing you
want to kind of want to do for all your
objects to set up shadow catchers shadow
catchers are going to allow you to put
shadows on the objects in the background
so here I'm just putting in a simple
plane and again because I have all those
points showing me where Josh is where
the table is where the floor is I can
quickly go in there and start lining
things up then I'm going to go ahead and
apply a shadow catching material to that
so that when the light passes through
that glass and through the liquid it's
gonna cast a shadow only on that object
the objects gonna be totally invisible
to the camera except for the shadows
then once I've got all that set up I've
got all my objects in there I'm gonna go
ahead and render every single object and
all the shadows out as separate passes
and bring those into my compositor once
I have all the objects and all the
shadows and everything I need rendered
I'll bring it in and then I start
compositing each element in individually
layering them together this is where a
node-based compositor really works well
versus something like After Effects
because you can split things off and
recombine them in your flow in a visual
way and it makes it just much easier to
combine all these elements into a final
shot as you can see I've got the TV the
debris blood a tooth floating in the air
the glasses bullet or n-- all those
different elements the shadows are all
rendered separately then combined in
fusion as a final composite pass and the
